scenes.background: The team has successfully completed an important project, and everyone is excited to organize a celebration. However, there are differing opinions on how to celebrate. Colleague Sam suggests going to a bar for a lively party, Emma prefers a formal dinner, and Ryan proposes an outdoor team-building activity. Alex suggests a bit of everything: starting with an outdoor activity, then having dinner, and ending the night at a bar. Monica and Bob have been discussing this, and you notice some tension as they approach you. Monica crosses her arms and says, 'Alex, do you really think we can fit all that in one evening? And Bob here thinks we should just stick to one thing.' Bob nods in agreement, looking a bit annoyed. Alex insists that experiencing all three would be a memorable celebration and suggests giving it a try.
scenes.description: Monica sighs and says, 'Alright, but what if we end up rushing through everything and no one enjoys any of it?' Bob adds, 'Yeah, and some of us might not even want to go to a bar.'

options.text: I see your point. Maybe we need to prioritize and focus on what will make the majority happy.
options.analysis: This option shows a high level of emotional detection and empathy by considering the concerns of both Monica and Bob. It demonstrates good social skills and motivation to reach a compromise.

options.text: Let's give it a go and adjust as needed. If we feel rushed, we'll cut something out. Flexibility is key!
options.analysis: This choice shows good self-regulation and social skills but slightly lower empathy as it prioritizes sticking to the original plan and adapting on the fly.

options.text: If it's too complicated, we might as well just go with a simple dinner to avoid issues.
options.analysis: This option reflects empathy and emotional detection by considering everyone's opinion, but shows lower motivation as it avoids making a decisive call.
